newsitem.title: INDIA: India considering ways to plug oil pool deficit.
newsitem.headline: India considering ways to plug oil pool deficit.

text.p: The Indian government is considering ways to reduce a growing "oil pool" deficit stemming from subsidised domestic prices, junior Petroleum Minister T.R. Balu said on Tuesday.
"The ways and means of meeting the oil pool deficit is under the active consideration of the government," Balu told the lower house of parliament, the Lok Sabha.

Last week, Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said his government needed to take a bold decision to contain the oil pool deficit, estimated at 155 billion rupees ($4.32 billion) at the end of 1996/97 (April-March).

The oil pool account has fallen into deficit because the cost of subsidies keeping down the domestic prices of some petroleum products has not been fully offset by payments into the account from levies on non-subsidised petroleum products.
Analysts and economists have said the government would need to raise the domestic prices of major petroleum products by an average of 20 percent to curb the subsidy bill.
